title: 107_hr2645
content: The "Motor Donor Act" establishes a National Organ Donor Registry under the Public Health Service Act. The purposes of this subpart are to increase organ and tissue donor registrations, enhance information on donation, ensure accurate information on individual wishes, and provide grants for state donor registries through driver's license applications. The term 'motor vehicle driver's license' refers to any ID issued by a state motor vehicle authority. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national organ and tissue donor registry, consisting of individuals expressing intent to donate. The registry includes personal information and is coordinated with states and organ procurement organizations. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national organ and tissue donor registry, coordinated with states and organ procurement organizations. The Secretary will work with states to promote the establishment of registries through the driver's license process. Organ procurement organizations can access the Registry 24/7 with a password assigned by the Secretary. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national organ and tissue donor registry. The Secretary will disseminate a pamphlet to US citizens with information on organ donation and a website address for registration. Participation in the Registry does not affect organ allocation practices. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national organ and tissue donor registry where individuals can express their intent to donate. Participation in the Registry is not legally binding consent for donation, except as allowed by State law. Individuals can cancel their participation at any time, and the Secretary will promptly remove their information. The Secretary can award grants to States to implement State registries linked to driver's licenses. Each State applying for a grant under the Motor Donor Act must submit an application demonstrating procedures for individuals to make a legally binding organ and tissue donation gift when applying for a driver's license. The application must include assurances that the State procedures comply with specific requirements. The State procedures for driver's license applications must include an option for individuals to designate their intent to be an organ and tissue donor. The application should contain a question asking if the individual wishes to have the organ donor designation in the State registry or on their driver's license. The State procedures for driver's license applications require individuals to affirmatively answer a question to have their organ donor preference noted in the State registry or on their driver's license. Information must be forwarded to the Registry within 100 days of designation, including any changes in designation or address. The State procedures require individuals to affirmatively answer a question to have their organ donor preference noted in the State registry or on their driver's license. If an individual chooses not to have the designation included, their name will not be forwarded to the Registry. Information of those who opt-in will be accessible to organ procurement organizations 24/7 without any fees. The Secretary gives priority in awarding grants to States collaborating with organ procurement organizations. Grants awarded to a State cannot exceed $300,000. An advisory task force on organ and tissue donation, consisting of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience, is established. The advisory task force on organ and tissue donation consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience with organ donations, procurement, or transplants. At least 1 member must be a physician with transplant experience, and another member must have organ procurement experience. Members serve 3-year terms, with staggered initial terms, and vacancies are filled promptly. The Task Force on organ and tissue donation, consisting of 5 members appointed by the Secretary, operates without being affected by vacancies. It can partner with the Coalition on Donation for a national awareness campaign and must submit a report with recommendations for improving the Registry and increasing public awareness. The Task Force members do not receive compensation but can claim travel expenses. Federal employees can be detailed to the Task Force without reimbursement. The Task Force members do not receive compensation but can claim travel expenses. Federal employees can be detailed to the Task Force without reimbursement, and the Department of Health and Human Services will provide administrative support. The Task Force is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Task Force activities. The amounts appropriated for the Task Force activities will remain available until expended. "Subpart 2--Organ Procurement" is an amendment of the Internal Revenue Code. Section 6103(m) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer information to the Department of Health and Human Services for the purpose of contacting individuals regarding the national organ and tissue donor registry. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Subpart 2 of part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended in sections 374(a), 374(d), 375(1), and 378, by replacing "this part" with "this subpart".
